conclusion: Shadows are cast by four objects: a sandal (A), a cake (B), a battery (C), and an unknown object (D). The light source is positioned above the objects.
When the light source moves backward, it increases the angle between the light rays and the surface.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will shift toward the opposite direction of the light's movement, meaning the shadows will move farther away from their respective objects.
The angle of the light rays becomes more oblique as the light source moves backward, resulting in longer shadows.
Therefore, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will become larger.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift farther from their respective objects and will increase in size.
